unnormalised: Okay, so picture this: it's Monday morn, 9 AM sharp, and my inbox is already exploding. Scheduling meetings across different time zones is honestly more complicated than understanding my taxes! We've got a team in Mumbai, another in London, and then the boss, who's always jet-setting between New York and Delhi. It's a logistical nightmare, I tell you.

unnormalised: And don't even get me started on daylight savings. I swear, every year, it throws the entire schedule into a complete disarray. Suddenly, a 2 PM meeting becomes a 1 PM meeting, or worse, gets completely skipped because someone forgot to adjust their calendar. It's happened to the best of us!

Suddenly, a two P-M meeting becomes a one P-M meeting, or worse, gets completely skipped because someone forgot to adjust their calendar. It's happened to the best of us!

unnormalised: Then there are the holidays. Of course, everyone wants to take off for Diwali (around 10/24 this year, I think?), Christmas (12/25), and Eid. Which is totally understandable, but trying to find a time that works for everyone when half the office is on leave is like finding a needle in a haystack. I'm thinking maybe a company-wide shared calendar with everyone's leave marked clearly is a good way out?

unnormalised: I've tried using all sorts of scheduling tools, but they all seem to have their own quirks. Some of them don't handle Indian Standard Time (IST) properly, others are just plain confusing to use. I mean, I get it, we're all busy, but spending an hour just trying to schedule a 30-min call? It's just not efficient. I wish some of these scheduling platforms would get their act together and accommodate for the Indian context a bit.
normalised: I've tried using all sorts of scheduling tools, but they all seem to have their own quirks. Some of them don't handle Indian Standard Time (I-S-T) properly, others are just plain confusing to use. I mean, I get it, we're all busy, but spending an hour just trying to schedule a thirty-minute call? It's just not efficient. I wish some of these scheduling platforms would get their act together and accommodate for the Indian context a bit.

unnormalised: The best trick, I've found, is to 'prepone' rather than postpone. If you think it'll take 3 weeks, ask for two. It gives you some buffer to reschedule, or 'adjust' in our special Indian way. That strategy has saved my rear more times than I'd like to admit.
normalised: The best trick, I've found, is to 'prepone' rather than postpone. If you think it'll take three weeks, ask for two. It gives you some buffer to reschedule, or 'adjust' in our special Indian way. That strategy has saved my rear more times than I'd like to admit.

unnormalised: And speaking of 'adjustments' - the concept of 'IST' for Indian Stretching Time is SO real. Meetings planned for 11:00 AM rarely actually start *before* 11:15 AM. Building this "buffer" into my planning has been a life-saver! Honestly.
normalised: And speaking of 'adjustments' - the concept of 'I-S-T' for Indian Stretching Time is S-O real. Meetings planned for eleven zero zero A-M rarely actually start *before* eleven fifteen A-M. Building this "buffer" into my planning has been a life-saver! Honestly.

unnormalised: One time, I accidentally scheduled a meeting for 12:00 AM IST thinking it was noon, only to realize later that it was midnight! The London team wasn't too thrilled to join a call in the middle of the night, let me tell you. Lesson learned: double-check the time zones, always!
normalised: One time, I accidentally scheduled a meeting for twelve zero zero A-M I-S-T thinking it was noon, only to realize later that it was midnight! The London team wasn't too thrilled to join a call in the middle of the night, let me tell you. Lesson learned: double-check the time zones, always!

unnormalised: So, yeah, scheduling across time zones is definitely a challenge. But with a little patience, a few good tools, and a whole lot of chai, we somehow manage to make it work. Maybe I'll invest in a really big world clock for my desk. Though, knowing my luck, it'd probably stop working at 3:30 PM on a Friday.
